timeline.title: Time-based Conditional Access
timeline.text:
When opening a conditional access policy in the Azure Portal, the backend fetches the policy object through the https://main.iam.ad.ext.azure.com.mcas.ms/api API. This object contains all the configurations of this policy including policyname, users, client applications, all the conditions and the controls. This conditions have the following categories:

  • Client apps
  • Device platforms
  • Device state
  • locations
  • Sign-in risk
  • User risk
  • Time

The time object is not configurable in the Azure Portal, but is included in each policy. It seems like a feature in development where office-hours or time-ranges can be configured. This would not fully prevent an attack, but helps build your layered defense. Modifying the creating or editing request of this policy does not have any effect.

An example of this object, which is included in each policy, below:

timeline.title: Launched jbaes.be
timeline.text:
Why?

The first reason to create this online curriculum vitae and blog is because I want to learn and improve my development skills in Angular and Angular Material. JavaScript and design frameworks are frequently used nowadays and so I think it is useful to know the basics of several. I've also had this 1-year free domain but I never used it for something 'public', besides to host some temporary site projects. This way, I make optimal use of it.

A second reason for this blog is because I wanted to share my experiences, thoughts and reflections with certain programs, operating systems, ideas, concepts or courses. Not that many of you will benefit from this, but it does helps me to process and reflect certain topics.

Tell me more about Angular

Angular is a web framework developed by Google. Although it is not the most used and popular JavaScript framework, I want to give it a try. A JavaScript framework gives you a environment with pre-written code and techniques to use. A front end framework allows you for example to use and re-use components. Building a house with tools and pre-manufactured materials like bricks, wood and cement is much more comfortable than creating your own building materials from scratch without a schema or blueprint. Or am I wrong?

Here I will compare the 3 most popular JavaScript frameworks:

Angular React Vue
Briefly The complete package Stable, requires lots of libraries Lightweight and simple
Popularity Mhwaa, not that much Yeah Uhum, used a lot!
Size and load time Depends, ¬± 600 KB! ¬± 130 KB ¬± 60 KB
Difficulty Takes a lot of time Not that easy Easy peasy

This will give you an idea of these frameworks. For beginners, I would suggest using Vue.js, just like I did. It is really powerful and fast, especially in combination with Vuetify. It will give you almost anything you need and is relatively simple to learn. Over the last few years it has become more and more popular.

Tell me more about Angular Material

Angular Material is a design framework for UX/UI components. It will let you implement interactive and visual good looking components like toolbars, buttons, forms, cards, dialogs, etc. And all of this, with minimal of CSS for you! Isn't that perfect.

In this blog, I use it in combination with Bootstrap. Material is in some ways limited, where Bootstrap strikes in.

Let's reflect

After making the basics of this website, I can say that I feel comfortable with Angular and material. I have had few problems and did not have a hard time adjusting my thinking. Probably because I already had experience with Vue.js. Material is really fantastic, yet it doesn't meet what I expect from a UI framework. The only thing that bothers me is the relative long loading time of Angular. Right now, the load time of the home page of this website is 1.6 seconds and it has a page size of 759.0 KB. I think that is still a bit to long for this simple and lightweight website. I will keep improving this!

I am absolutely happy with the result I created within a few hours and wouldn't really change much.

timeline.title: Livestream webcam with viewer detection
timeline.text:
A good friend (Casper Haems) and I were instructed by a local non-profit organization to upgrade their webcam. At that time, they had a camera mounted that took a picture every minute and published it on their website. This camera was portforwarded and therefore publicly available to everyone, which is absolutely not necessary in this situation. On top of that, it used default credentials, the software of the camera was outdated and probably had a ton of vulnerabilities and didn't function 100% anymore.

Without discussing it, Casper and I knew that we wouldn't use a commercial webcam but would work with a Raspberry Pi and a small webcam instead. This because a Raspberry is relatively cheap, powerful and customizable compared to a commercial webcam. Also because implementation would be more flexible and we would not have to deal with outdated software as we would write it ourselves. The only problem is, that if YouTube changes its API, we could have some trouble.

How it works

When a user starts the livestream from the website using a button, a value is changed in the database. The Raspberry Pi will notice this and depending on the value, start or stop livestreaming.

When the Raspberry Pi is streaming, it and the user will constantly turn the toggle in the database on and off. When the user leaves the website, the toggle will not be changed by the user and the picam will stop streaming after a certain amount of time. Then the livestream value in the database will also be turned off again. Ready for the next stream!

Here is a visual overview of how the system works.

And here what is looks like for the user;

The software

This is the code on the Raspberry Pi. It is polling the status of the livestream that contains 3 values:

  • If the livestream if currently active
  • If the killswitch is on
  • If a user is watching the livestream

Based on these values, it starts, continues or stops the stream.

import time from subprocess
import Popen
import os, signalimport json
import urllib as urllib2
import request
import datetime

endpoind_start = ""
endpoint_stop = ""
endpoint_fetch = ""
endpoint_toggle = ""
command_start = "raspivid -o - -t 0 -vf -hf -fps 24 -b 6000000 -rot 180 | ffmpeg -re -ar 44100 -ac 2 -acodec pcm_s16le -f s16le -ac 2 -i /dev/zero -f h264 -i - -vcodec copy -acodec aac -ab 128k -g 50 -strict experimental -f flv [rtmp-url]"

def start_livestream():
    global p
    print('starting livestream...')
    urllib2.urlopen(endpoind_start).read()
    p = Popen(command_start, shell=True, preexec_fn=os.setsid)

def stop_livestream():
    global p
    print('Stopping livestream...')
    urllib2.urlopen(endpoind_stop).read()
    print(p.pid, signal.SIGKILL)
    os.killpg(os.getpgid(p.pid), signal.SIGTERM)

def fetchData():
    return json.load(urllib2.urlopen(endpoint_fetch))

def switch_toggle():
    urllib2.urlopen(endpoint_toggle).read()

counter = 0
flag_stopped = false
switch_toggle()
urllib2.urlopen(endpoint_stop).read()
while True:
    if 8 <= datetime.datetime.now().hour < 22:
        try:
            flag_stopped = true
            data = fetchData()
            livestream = data[0]['value'];
            livestream_killswitch = data[1]['value'];
            livestream_stop = data[2]['value'];
            # print(livestream, livestream_killswitch, livestream_stop)
            if livestream == "true":
                if livestream_stop == "true":
                    counter += 1
                else:
                    counter = 0
                switch_toggle()
                if counter > 15 or livestream_killswitch == "true":
                    stop_livestream()
            else:
                if livestream_stop == "false" and livestream_killswitch == "false":
                    start_livestream()
        except Exception as exception:
                print('major error', exception)
                continue
        except KeyboardInterrupt:
            print('Stopped service using KeyboardInterrupt')
            exit()
        time.sleep(2)
    else:
        if flag_stopped == false:
            stop_livestream()
            flag_stopped = true

Conclusion

This camera has been active since the beginning of Septemer 2019 and has been streaming live for quite a long time without any problems. In the beginning, we used FireBase, but we would get a quota exceeded error, so we switch to an MySQL database. We have also received a request from another organization that we have not discussed yet if we could accept. At the time of writing this post, there are 1500+ videos made by the picam. For privacy reasons we regularly put videos private so we don't create a platform with years of video footage, even though most of the people visible on the footage are barely recognizable.

Update Sept. 19th 2020:
On September 12th around 15h00, we noticed a problem. YouTube could't display the iframe of the livestream anymore. After reading some API documentation, and not finding any updates since 2019 that could be the reason of the inoperative Pi, we concluded that the best thing we could do is change streaming platform. From now on, we are using Twitch.tv.
